item.title: Secondary School Student Performance
item.description: 1 Introduction 2 Prepare 3 Get started 3.1 Population vs Sample 3.2 How to infer from a sample to a population 3.2.1 Normal Distrubution 3.2.2 Central Tendency 3.2.3 Dispersion 3.2.4 Confidence interval 3.2.5 Z-score 3.2.6 skew and kurtosis analysis 3.2.7 Hypothesis Testing 3.2.8 Shapiro–Wilk test 3.2.9 Using Normal Distribution to find outliers 3.3 Missing Data 3.4 More 4 Explore 5 Analysis 6 Model 7 Report 8 Using R References 1 Introduction 2 Prepare We explore a student exam performance data set.

item.title: About
item.description: Hi, I’m Brendan and I write blogs about data science and hopefully other stuff. Thanks to https://github.com/jrutheiser/hugo-lithium-theme for the Hugo theme.

item.title: Description
item.description: body{ /* Normal */ font-size: 10px; } code.r{ /* Code block */ font-size: 10px; } pre { /* Code block - determines code spacing between lines */ font-size: 10px; } Handy copy of the data description # Attributes for both student-mat.csv (Math course) and student-por.csv (Portuguese language course) datasets: 1 school - student's school (binary: "GP" - Gabriel Pereira or "MS" - Mousinho da Silveira) 2 sex - student's sex (binary: "F" - female or "M" - male) 3 age - student's age (numeric: from 15 to 22) 4 address - student's home address type (binary: "U" - urban or "R" - rural) 5 famsize - family size (binary: "LE3" - less or equal to 3 or "GT3" - greater than 3) 6 Pstatus - parent's cohabitation status (binary: "T" - living together or "A" - apart) 7 Medu - mother's education (numeric: 0 - none, 1 - primary education (4th grade), 2 – 5th to 9th grade, 3 – secondary education or 4 – higher education) 8 Fedu - father's education (numeric: 0 - none, 1 - primary education (4th grade), 2 – 5th to 9th grade, 3 – secondary education or 4 – higher education) 9 Mjob - mother's job (nominal: "teacher", "health" care related, civil "services" (e.
